title: How to Find Photo Ops

steps.headline: Don't expect your photo op to jump up and down and say, 'Over Here!
Look for something simple.
steps.description: 'Break' something down to its basic visual appeal.

steps.headline: Look for a viewpoint that can simplify things.
steps.description: In the image above, the perspective has been changed to make it more appealing.

steps.headline: Always take into consideration the background.
steps.description: Will it add to an image, or do you need to blur it to keep it from detracting from the image. Maybe you can zoom in close enough to totally get rid of the background.

steps.headline: Look for something that can be photographed.
steps.description: If there are aspects that make it difficult or impossible, such as harsh lighting, cluttered foreground or background, or rotten depth of field, then keep looking.

steps.headline: Remember that not every image has to be an award winner.
steps.description: Instead of looking for that 'perfect' photo, look for ones that have potential.

steps.headline: Quit looking.
steps.description: Maybe you are looking too hard and you need to relax. Wander around where you are and just look. Most likely, something will jump out at you screaming, 'Photo Op! '.

steps.headline: Stay positive.
steps.description: Don't even think about what can't be done. Consider what can be done and keep that perspective.

steps.headline: Explore.
steps.description: Just walk around and explore the area. See what's there.

steps.headline: Stop and analyze.
steps.description: Is there nothing that is interesting? Nothing at all? If so, maybe you should switch locations, or take a break.
